verses.text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, according to the promise of life that is in Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Paul affirms his apostolic authority is by God's will. The 'promise of life in Christ Jesus' points to the core of the Gospel message—eternal life through union with Christ. See also John 5:24 for the promise of eternal life.

verses.text: To Timothy, my beloved child: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: 'Beloved child' shows the close spiritual relationship between Paul and Timothy, reflecting spiritual fatherhood in ministry (see also 1 Cor. 4:15).

verses.text: I give thanks to God, whom I serve with a clear conscience as did my ancestors, when I remember you constantly in my prayers night and day.
verses.comment: Paul's reference to his ancestors implies continuity of faith from Israel to the church. Unceasing prayer for others is highlighted for spiritual leadership.

verses.text: As I remember your tears, I yearn to see you that I may be filled with joy.
verses.comment: Their relationship is deeply personal. The reference to Timothy's tears reveals early Christian leaders shared real emotion and encouraged companionship in ministry.

verses.text: I am reminded of your sincere faith, a faith that first lived in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice, and now, I am sure, lives in you as well.
verses.comment: Faith passed on from generation to generation is emphasized—highlighting the spiritual heritage of family and traditions in passing on the faith (see also Deut. 6:7).

verses.text: For this reason I remind you to rekindle the gift of God which is in you through the laying on of my hands.
verses.comment: Here, the transmission of spiritual gifts through laying on of hands refers to apostolic succession and sacramental ministry—points to an early church practice.

verses.text: For God gave us not a spirit of fear, but of power and love and self-control.
verses.comment: The Holy Spirit empowers Christians not with fear but with strength and love. 'Self-control' (sophronismos) points to spiritual discipline—lived out in holiness.

verses.text: Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord, nor of me his prisoner, but share in suffering for the Gospel by the power of God,
verses.comment: Paul urges courage and sharing in suffering—suffering seen as a participation in Christ’s own sufferings (cf. 1 Pet. 4:13).

verses.text: who saved us and called us to a holy calling, not because of our works but because of his own purpose and grace, which he gave us in Christ Jesus before time began,
verses.comment: Salvation and calling are due to divine grace, not human effort. The phrase 'before time began' shows salvation’s roots in God’s eternal plan—a profound mystery.

verses.text: and now has been revealed through the appearing of our Savior Christ Jesus, who destroyed death and brought life and immortality to light through the gospel,
verses.comment: Christ’s incarnation revealed God’s eternal purpose. Conquering death fulfills OT prophecy and shows Jesus’ divinity through his victory and power to grant immortality.

verses.text: for which I was appointed a preacher and apostle and teacher.
verses.comment: Paul’s triple calling reflects different aspects of ministry—proclaiming, sent with authority, and instructing the faithful. Implies ordered ministry and leadership.

verses.text: That is why I suffer these things; but I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed, and I am convinced that he is able to guard what I have entrusted to him until that Day.
verses.comment: Paul’s faith rests on his personal relationship with Christ. 'That Day' refers to the final judgment and hope in the resurrection (John 6:39-40).

verses.text: Hold fast to the pattern of sound words that you heard from me, in the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes maintaining the apostolic teaching as a ‘pattern’. Faith does not change with culture; there is a received deposit of faith carefully guarded.

verses.text: Guard the good deposit entrusted to you by the Holy Spirit who dwells within us.
verses.comment: The 'good deposit' refers to apostolic tradition, preserved through the Spirit and entrusted to church leadership. Implies the necessity to preserve sound teaching through all generations.

verses.text: You are aware that all who are in Asia turned away from me, among whom are Phygelus and Hermogenes.
verses.comment: Paul’s abandonment reveals human weakness even among early Christians but also highlights the value of perseverance despite setbacks or disappointments.

verses.text: May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains,
verses.comment: Paul prays for mercy on Onesiphorus and his household, showing prayer for others, including the faithful departed, was practiced (cf. 2 Tim. 4:19).

verses.text: but when he arrived in Rome, he searched for me earnestly and found me—
verses.comment: Personal loyalty in Christian fellowship is honored and encouraged. Onesiphorus’s effort is an example of perseverance in love and service.

verses.text: may the Lord grant him to find mercy from the Lord on that Day! And you know very well how much service he rendered at Ephesus.
verses.comment: Paul offers an intercessory prayer for Onesiphorus 'on that Day,' expressing hope for mercy at final judgment, and points out the efficacy of prayer for others, including beyond this life.
